text:
216 to 226 Hudson Street (left), at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Watts Street. Also shown are Nos. 108 to 94 Watts Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Hudson Street. The corner building bears No. 216 Hudson and 108 Watts Streets. These buildings were demolished during the construction of the Holland Tunnel and today (1937) this entire block is the Plaza to entrance of same. December 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Another view of the same location, at an earlier date. Note the abandoned appearance of the Watts Street buildings.

About 1900

Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beacher Ogden

216 to 226 Hudson Street (left), at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of Watts Street. Also shown are Nos. 108 to 94 Watts Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Hudson Street. The corner building bears No. 216 Hudson and 108 Watts Streets. These buildings were demolished during the construction of the Holland Tunnel and today (1937) this entire block is the Plaza to entrance of same. December 1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Another view of the same location, at an earlier date. Note the abandoned appearance of the Watts Street buildings.

About 1900

Thomas W. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beacher Ogden

Canal Street (right), north side, from Hudson to Varick Streets, and Watts Street (left), north side, east from Hudson. The Watts Street buildings will be demolished in the mid 1920's for the Holland Tunnel Plaza.

1908.

Brown Brothers.

Hudson Street (right), east side, south from Canal Street; Also shown is Canal Street (left), south side, east from Hudson Street, showing at the corner (S.E.) Salmon's Pharmacy with the New York Central Railroad tracks (Hudson Street, right) passing its door. Buildings shown at this corner, were razed in approximately 1928 and on their site was erected the 12-story Green Terminal Building. On Canal Street, extending to Varick Street (where street car is visible) is now also the exit of the Holland Tunnel.

1908.

Brown Brothers.

(1)

461 to 481 Canal Street, north side, east of, adjoining, and at the east corner of Hudson Street.
October 10, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same part of the block, looking northwest, after the demolition of the old buildings.
February 12, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

461 to 481 Canal Street, north side, east of, adjoining, and at the east corner of Hudson Street.
October 10, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same part of the block, looking northwest, after the demolition of the old buildings.
February 12, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, south side, west from Hudson (left), to Watts (right) Streets, showing a row of old buildings occupying this block front and which subsequently will be replaced by a 12 story loft structure (prior to 1932). The structure bearing the Miller Tompkins & Co. signs is to be reconstructed according to the N.Y. times of October 20, 1937 and occupied by the firm of Magnus, Mabee & Reynard Inc. of 257 pearl Street, dealers in essential oils. It will have translucent glass fronts on both its Desbrosses (No. 16) and Watts (No. 119-21) Street sides. Note on the latter thoroughfare, the Ninth Avenue "El" running on Greenwich Street.

September 27, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Watts Street, south side, from No. 99, east of Hudson Street, to No. 51, east of Varick, inclusive. Nos. 99 to 75, the group of old houses west of, adjoining and at Varick Street, S.W. corner, are shortly to be demolished for the site of the Holland Plaza Building. A number of these old houses are brick faced frame houses, specifically Nos. 91-89, 83, 81, 79, and 75 at the corner. The last is faced with brick on the 93 Varick Street side.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, seen from Hudson Street, four months later, when the entire block has been cleared off except for a few trees. The large white building is on the east side of Varick Street (q.v.) from Watts Street to Grand.
February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Watts Street, south side, from No. 99, east of Hudson Street, to No. 51, east of Varick, inclusive. Nos. 99 to 75, the group of old houses west of, adjoining and at Varick Street, S.W. corner, are shortly to be demolished for the site of the Holland Plaza Building. A number of these old houses are brick faced frame houses, specifically Nos. 91-89, 83, 81, 79, and 75 at the corner. The last is faced with brick on the 93 Varick Street side.
October 11, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, seen from Hudson Street, four months later, when the entire block has been cleared off except for a few trees. The large white building is on the east side of Varick Street (q.v.) from Watts Street to Grand.
February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Canal Street, north side, from Hudson to Varick Streets, inclusive, looking at Varick Street across the cleared triangular block where the Holland Plaza Building will rise. This is the block shown in Brown Brothers' 1908 view.

February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Hudson Street, east side, from Watts Street to Canal. The entire block bounded by Watts, Hudson, Canal, and Varick Streets, has been cleared, except for a few trees.

February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

219 to 259 Hudson Street, west side, at, adjoining, and north of Canal Street, N. W. corner. No. 241, the white house adjoining the vacant lot on the north, is a brick-faced frame, as are the three-story building at No.249 and the 4-story building adjoining it on the north, No. 253.
September 27, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

The same, and north to Spring Street, nearly six years later. A filling station has, since 1931, replaced Nos. 219, 221, 223 at the corner of Canal Street, Nos. 261, 263, 265, not shown in the first picture, are also brick-faced frame houses.
June 7, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

A detail of No. 1, showing the buildings that are razed in No. 2.
June 30, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

Lunch wagon, in the vacant lot 231-237 Hudson Street, west side, north of Watts Street.
February 25, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Squatters Colony: Shelters of the unemployed at (No. 1) West 76th Street and the North (Hudson) River, and at the Foot of Canal Street (No. 2). Both of these locations are incorrect according to the belief of the writer.

July 11, 1931
October 24, 1934

P. L. Sperr
title: Squatters Colony at the Hudson [North] River.

(1)
Holland Plaza, Hudson Street, east side, from Watts Street towards Broome, and just including the entrance to the Holland Vehicular Tunnel.
March 20, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a year later, including a little of the new building at the Nor-Ea corner of Broome Street.
June 3, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, showing a closer view of the entrance to the tube. Note the Church of Our Lady of Vilna R.C., No. 570 Broome Street, adjoining the N.W. corner of Varick Street.
July 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

Hudson Street, east side, at Canal Street. In the right foreground is a sentry box used by the railroad flagman. At this point the railroad tracks turn off Canal Street and down Hudson.
December 20, 1932,

P. L. Sperr.

247-249, 251-253 Hudson Street, west side, north of Canal Street, a rear view across the site of 22-26 Renwick Street, which were demolished around 1930.

About 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

253, 249, 245, 241 Hudson Street, west side, north of Canal Street and opposite the western end of Broome Street. No. 243-245, adjoining the light colored house next to the vacant lot, is a solid brick building, but the other three houses are frame with brick facings.

About 1932.

J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

259 to 275 Hudson Street, west side, between Canal and Spring Streets. Nos. 261-265, the three 3-story houses in the center of the picture are frame, faced with brick; the first being a brick structure. No. 271, the 5-story tenement just north of the last frame house will be demolished (1937).  1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

title: North (Hudson) River - Manhattan - Canal Street area - Battery - 14th Street - [Holland Tunnel Ventilation Building.]
North (Hudson) River - Manhattan - Canal Street area - Battery - 14th Street - [Holland Tunnel Ventilation Building.]

text:
Canal Street, north side, west from Hudson (right) to Renwick (left) Streets. The photographer is viewing northwest and includes at the right an extensive view up Hudson Street.

Views 2 and 3 are of the same locale, tho the latter veers eastward to show the westerly portion of the Holland Tunnel Plaza. The entrance to same adjoins the Board of Transportation Building, (Chevrolet sign). This structure occupies the entire easterly frontage of Hudson Street from Broome to Dominick Streets.

View 1: June 3, 1933
Views 2-3 July 26, 1935

P. L. Sperr

View 1:
View 2: Neg. # 1205
View 3:

(1) Hudson Street, west side, from Canal Street to Vandam, across east side from Canal to Spring. At the left, a freight train on Canal Street is shown turning south into Hudson Street.

(2) The same, and north of Vandam Street in the background, four yeaars later. The new building partially shown at the right is at the NE corner of Broome Street. June 7, 1933.

P. L. Sperr

June 3, 1933.

July 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Watts Street, north side, west from and including Hudson Street, to the Hudson River. Also shown is Hudson Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.W. corner of Watts Street. Note the Ninth Ave. Elevated on Greenwich Street.

July 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, further westward (at Renwick Street); and showing Canal Street, south side, west to West Street.

Hudson Street, east side, from Watts (left) to Canal (right) Streets, showing the lower floors of the 16-story Holland Plaza Building. On the right appears an extensive view eastward on Canal Street.

June 11, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Hudson Street, west side, north from Canal (left) to Vandam (center) Streets, as seen from Canal (immediate foreground) Street. The large structure of which only the lower floors appear is the Board of Transportation Building and is at the N.E. corner of Hudson and Broome Streets. To the right of same (not shown) is the entrance to the Holland Tunnel.

June 11, 1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

Hudson Street, east side and Canal Street looking northwards and showing the "L" at the Greenwich Street.

Manhattan Highways Comm.

January 26th, 1937

original_title: Manhattan: Canal Street - [Between Hudson and Watts Streets]
text:
12-story MALTZ INDUSTRIAL BUILDING on site owned by TRINITY CHURCH CORPORATION at 480 Canal Street, facing Holland Tunnel entrance. Leasehold covering property was sold recently by MALBERN CONSTRUCTION COMPANY to JUNIOR LEASING CORPORATION through WILLIAM S. SUSSMAN, INCORPORATED,
who have been appointed managing agents.
